Posts.Content: Hello lumpylady, love the name btw. I started blogging the day after my first chemo and I love it. I don't hold anything back (maybe some times I should). I think it's a great way for those around me to understand a little more of what we are going through. It's also helping me too, one day I will go back and read it and think wow I went through some difficult stuff and I got through it!  Dreamthief how do you highlight a name? Still not figured that one out! Regards Jo xx
Posts.Title: Blogging

Posts.Content: @Dreamthief I don't think it works unless it's case sensitive so I'm trying again!
Posts.Title: Blogging

Posts.Content: peachesxxx @dreamthief  yes it's a Wordpress I think www.josjubblygetscancer wondered why it didn't come up with link, forgot the .com! www.josjubblygetscancer.com  Hopefully that works. The @ thing doesn't work on my phone
Posts.Title: Blogging

Posts.Content: @dreamthief  yes it's a Wordpress I think www.josjubblygetscancer
Posts.Title: Blogging

Posts.Content: Thank you for posting this Louise. I've always wondered what the difference is, maybe I should have just asked! Haha I'm two weeks post my first AC, second one due next Friday. Good luck  Jo xx
Posts.Title: AC Chemo

Posts.Content: Good luck Lou, I hope the cold cap works for you xxx
Posts.Title: AC Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Louise, I too was grade 3. I've only had AC, I'm due 4 cycles so quarter of the way through. Cold cap was never mentioned but I'd already decided I didn't want it. Quite liking my shaved head, I keep stroking myself!  I had it on the Friday and was good until Monday then spent all week pretty much in bed. I've been good this past week. I'm writing a blog most days about everything, I'm finding it's helping loads.  This really has been the hardest thing I've ever had to do but it's only temporary.  It's funny how we all react differently. I think I've got off lightly compared to some. Good luck  Jo xx
Posts.Title: AC Chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you Lou, it's really helped me and those around me. I was oblivious to it all and quite rightly so, unless you go through it you aren't to know. Maybe been a bit too honest at times haha  Yes ER+ Her- I was grade 3 (original biopsy grade 2) 0/1 and the blood vessels + but can't remember the abbreviations for that one xx
Posts.Title: AC Chemo

Posts.Content: To be honest so far I've not really thought about anything too much, I've just gone on with it.  Ok I have breast cancer what do I do about it? Ok I need a lumpectomy when will I have it? Ok it's chemo next when will I have it and what do I need to do to prepare?  I too work in a school (I'm an LSA) so haven't been back to school after breaking up for summer. I've made myself busy with knowledge and the practical side of things. I've been so positive about everything and that's what's kept me going forward.  I wouldn't want something that might help, I needed something that will help xx
Posts.Title: Brca 1 ... the journey .... chemotherapy and more !

Posts.Content: With the hair loss, the day after the oncologist told me chemo I cut my long hair into a pixie cut. I needed my family and myself to get used to it shorter. I started my chemo yesterday and know it will be around day 12 I will start to lose it. Wednesday I went to have my wig fitting. Was the most excited I'd been for ages. Afterwards I had my head shaved. Again I needed the time to process it all. I haven't yet worn the wig. I don't want to be reliant on it, also want my children to get used to me with little hair. I can't stop stroking my head, it feels so nice and I actually prefer it to the pixie cut. But, we are all different and view things differently xxx
Posts.Title: Brca 1 ... the journey .... chemotherapy and more !

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda, I'm 44 and had my ovaries removed last year when I had my hysterectomy as my aunt has ovarian cancer. Mum was diagnosed with BC at 51 but both of theirs was classed as age onset so no testing offered. When I was diagnosed with BC in August I contacted my genetic lady again and had the BRCA test on 12 September so currently waiting for results. My BC was grade 3, her2 neg and oestrogen +, I had a lumpectomy. My first chemo session was yesterday and I'm to have radiotherapy after. I've already decided if the BRCA is positive I will opt for double mx. Everyone is different. I've got the support of my friends and family but when it comes down to it it has to be a personal decision. Wishing you all the best. Jo xx
Posts.Title: Brca 1 ... the journey .... chemotherapy and more !

Posts.Content: I was exactly the same with going into mum/wife mode. i finished chemo in December and radiotherapy in February but these past few weeks I'm an emotional wreck! I had long hair which I had cut to a pixie cut a few weeks before chemo. I then had it shaved to a number 2 the day before chemo and I have to say, I actually loved it. I'd bought a wig which I only wore twice. I preferred my bald head. I was so glad I shaved it before it started falling out as my head got so sore with chemo, I couldn't have coped with anything touching my head.  Good luck Jo xx
Posts.Title: Breast cancer, hair loss and sheer worry

Posts.Content: Thank you both for your replies. I've never had a reaction or been poorly after the jab and I've been having it for years.  I phoned the doctor and have booked myself in for next weekend. I'm seeing the oncologist for the first time tomorrow so will ask him and if need be postpone. Thank you again x
Posts.Title: Flu jab and chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you for your comments. I'm taking paracetamol and ibuprofen regularly too. I am moving, well trying to. I've been given some leg stretches exercises to do. My friend recommended Epsom salt baths and red tiger balm which hubby got yesterday. At the hospital they mentioned physiology and even surgery but I did just switch off and say I can't even think of that. I'm going to call the unit again in the morning. Surely not just coincidence it started 36 hours after? I've thought of massage as my body is so tense, shoulders are hard as lead but think I'd cry if anyone even stroked their fingers over me! Just want to feel human again! xxx
Posts.Title: Leg pain, advice needed

Posts.Content: Hi Lou, what side effects do you have from flu jab? I have one every year being diabetic and never had anything more than a sore arm where they inject. My oncologist said it was really good for me to have it before I start the chemo. I had the jab last week and start on the 7th. The nurse at the drs said it takes 14 days to get the full affect so was good I had a two week gap. Do you have someone you can ring just to clarify it all for you? Jo x
Posts.Title: Flu jabs?

Posts.Content: Thank you, yes he agreed it was good that's I'm booked in to get it done next week before I start Jo x
Posts.Title: Flu jab and chemo

Posts.Content: I've just received my letter inviting me for my flu jab (I'm diabetic). Yesterday I was told I will be having chemo. Is this something I should do before? Obviously I will discuss with my oncologist but just wondering on your views? Regards Jo x
Posts.Title: Flu jab and chemo

Posts.Content: Hello, I'll try the short version. 3rd AC chemo 9 days ago. 2 days after woke with excruciating pain in calf and hip. Phoned unit said couldn't link to chemo. Went to dr possible trapped nerve given naproxen. Back to dr Thursday as in agony. Sent to hospital with suspected clot. Blood marker raised, had scan Friday, no clot. They've said nerve damage and given me gabapentin, said will take at least three weeks to work. Well I'm in absolute agony. I can't walk, I scream if I move. This pain is actually worse than labour. It eases a bit if I lay down so I'm pretty much confined to bed. If I get up I'm just sobbing. Any advice will be gratefully received, don't know how much longer I can go on like this Jo xx
Posts.Title: Leg pain, advice needed

Posts.Content: i had my chemo ore-assessment yesterday. The unit and staff were lovely, instantly relax when you walk through the doors. Explained so much, head full of information. I got my wig voucher and have made an appointment for next Wednesday - I even get a trip to the seaside to do it! That was all good, then I had optician. My eyes haven't been right lately. She found a large bleed behind my left eye (diabetic retinopathy) and sent me straight to A&E! By the time I was seen (although was seen very quickly) the eye clinic was closed so was sent home waiting for them to call me. My blood pressure was 168/108. I need to get that down and sugar levels or I'm at risk of another bleed which will eventually take my vision. I'm so upset, probably doesn't help hubby being away. How much is one person supposed to cope with?! I'm going to take the girls to our caravan once they are up. Hoping a change of scenery will help - I have a nice colouring book there! Sorry for the long post. I did write this last night but when I went to post it said I wasn't a member, very strange  Take care people  Jo xx
Posts.Title: So fed up

Posts.Content: I'm feeling so frustrated today. Was told Wednesday I'm to have chemo and a nurse will be in touch within the week to give me a date to go in to meet them and for them to go through everything. I'm just so fed up with waiting! I am really struggling. Even if they called to say it's not going to be until such a date I'd feel better. All we seem to do it wait! Kiddies at school, hubby at work probably and me being off is probably not helping as I'm bored. I've been for walks, tried to read book, had friends over but I'm exhausted but too exhausted to sleep. Any advice how to relax would be gratefully received! Regards Jo xx
Posts.Title: Feeling frustrated

Posts.Content: Thank you for your reply Julia, yes I will give Pinterest a browse (keeps me away from Amazon).  I spent yesterday organising things, dentist, dr, ordered some Christmas pressies etc. I've arranged for kiddies to have Christmas with their dad too. My chemo will be coming to an end then but don't want to ruin their day just in case - he hasn't had them for a few years over Christmas and they'll only be down the road so we can pop in. I should make the most of this time off and the peace and quiet. I'm usually such a busy person I find it hard! I'm struggling with sleep as down my side and on my arm feels like I have severe sunburn still from the nerve endings. A box set sounds good too, will have a search. Thank you xx
Posts.Title: Feeling frustrated

Posts.Content: Funny I said to my husband yesterday about getting a bucket to go under the bed even though I'm about 4 steps from the toilet!  I've ordered a few cotton headscarves, today was the makeup brushes (to practice eyebrows), provisions in place for picking little one up and taking to school. My friend is fostering my dog for a few months - just done home visit and will have few more get to know visits.  I'm ready and just want to get this next stage - the hardest part, started. I won't ring as I know every one of us is in the same boat, I need to learn to be patient and like my own company. xxx
Posts.Title: Feeling frustrated

Posts.Content: Hello,mine came back as 4.9% I was told 5% is when they say definitely chemo. I was offered to have it sent to America to get a more accurate result but as I was only 0.1% away from the definite I agreed. When I saw my oncologist for the first time, he said he recommended I have chemo.  I am 44 and have 5 children, again I wanted to be able to say I did everything I thought I possibly could to prevent it from coming back and in my head that is chemo.  I don't know how you get the percentage for it coming back, no one has told me that.  Yes chemo is tough on everyone, not just me but it is doable. My chemo nurse told me that the morality rate for chemo is 8-10% but, thought figured include terminal and very elderly patients. Think they need to break down their statistics along the way but the end of the day they are only statistics. Good luck with your decision  Jo xx
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and should I have chemo?

Posts.Content: im glad it's feeling much better but definitely take it easy, keep up with the RICE - rest, ice, compression and elevation. My aunt fell during chemo, broke both her ankles and took ages to recover. Take care Jo x
Posts.Title: Twisted ankle and feeling miserable

Posts.Content: This morning I saw my genetic consultant and had the blood test for the BRCA mutation. Just 6-8 weeks to wait for that. This afternoon I went for my results following the lumpectomy 18 days ago. It was grade 3 not 2 as previously thought. Lymph nodes were clear so that bit is excellent. I'm seeing the oncologist on Wednesday and will be having chemo followed by radiotherapy.  I've told all the kiddies, my 9 year old has offered to shave her hair off to show her support - got to love her but obviously have told her there's no need.  Feeling a bit dizzy from it all, really wasn't expecting it!
Posts.Title: Not the results I was hoping

Posts.Content: Thank you for the reply Carolyn, yes it's the grading that topped it. It's Her2- Haha yes definitely won't be showing her that!
Posts.Title: Not the results I was hoping

Posts.Content: Hi Loulou have you been told chemo will not be the best option? I'm insulin dependant diabetic and I start my chemo Friday. No one has really mentioned my diabetes in all this (was actually a welcome break, everything is usually "because you're diabetic"). It was mentioned at my ore-assessment last week that my sugars will probably be a bit unstable. I'd already spoken to my diabetic team and someone is coming to see me Friday while I'm having chemo.  When is your next appointment? Wishing you all the best Jo xx
Posts.Title: I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: Thank you all. Yes G n' J that's exactly what went around my head lol yes they are doing the sentinel node biopsy.  I am so lucky, the hospital are fantastic and everyone is so nice, just, like everyone else, I wasn't expecting to go through this xx
Posts.Title: Results are back

Posts.Content: Hi Loulou have you been told chemo will not be the best option? I'm insulin dependant diabetic and I start my chemo Friday. No one has really mentioned my diabetes in all this (was actually a welcome break, everything is usually "because you're diabetic"). It was mentioned at my ore-assessment last week that my sugars will probably be a bit unstable. I'd already spoken to my diabetic team and someone is coming to see me Friday while I'm having chemo.  When is your next appointment? Wishing you all the best Jo xx
Posts.Title: I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: Thank you. Didn't sleep very well last night. I'm trying not to think much but think my brain has a mind of its own! Feeling very tearful today but this is the first time since diagnosis - I can't be cheerful every day. It's people's kindness which gets me blubbering!
Posts.Title: Not the results I was hoping

Posts.Content: I went back yesterday (week after biopsy) and they have confirmed that I do have breast cancer. It's invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 2, oestrogen positive.  I've got my pre-op in the morning and lumpectomy next Thursday. She said depending on results of lymph nodes whether I'll need chemo or radiotherapy. It's all going a bit too quick - although grateful for the speed. They said within 31 days so I was thinking around 30 lol She said I'll be on hormone therapy for 10-15 years after
Posts.Title: Results are back

Posts.Content: I had one too, was like a tennis ball. Sounds like a sermonina (sorry can't spell). Ring your BCN this morning as you may need it drained xx
Posts.Title: Lump under arm after op

Posts.Content: Hello, had my long hair chopped this morning in readiness for my chemo to begin. Now I'm thinking of eyebrows. Has anyone had microblading before rather than tattoo? Really appreciate any comments  Regards Jo xx
Posts.Title: Microblading eyebrows

Posts.Content: Hello, I've not been on for a while but do 'pop in' every now and then. I have a question about my hair. I finished chemo the beginning of December 16. I have nearly 3" of hair now which is really curly. For those of you who also went curly, does it stay like this or do they fall out?  I am finally starting to not mind it, especially since I've been experimenting with hair bands! Hope everyone is doing well Jo xxx
Posts.Title: Hair after chemo

Posts.Content: I've just seen my oncologist and I'm to have 4 cycles of AC chemo. The chemo nurses will call within the week to arrange an hour long appointment so go through everything. Said I probably won't be back at work until after Easter (I'm a teaching assistant), I've just popped into school to tell them, they are just great! I'm feeling ok at the moment, just want a date so we can start this long recovery process!
Posts.Title: AC chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Thank you Lynn, I tried to get an appointment with dentist but the are full until end of October so I've booked in with the hygienist to have a good clean before. Flu jab already booked in for next week and my B12 injection. Today I had my long hair cut into a short pixie cut. Was more nervous doing that than getting my results but I see it as first step to my recovery!  Jo xx
Posts.Title: AC chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Thinking of you this morning xx
Posts.Title: I need help please.

Posts.Content: Thanks Elaine, they told me the biospy results were grade 2 oestrogen positive her2 negative. I'm guessing it doesn't change once it's out?  Yes I've read up on that test. Good luck Jo x
Posts.Title: Post Op results

Posts.Content: Well done, that's really good news. I am two weeks (tomorrow) post lumpectomy. I'm going for my results Monday, i thought everything would be told then, didn't know you'd have to wait even longer for other results! I was told when I had my biopsy results that it was Her2- is it different what you're waiting for? Sorry to ask questions, all so strange to me but very happy for you. Jo x
Posts.Title: Post Op results

Posts.Content: I went this afternoon to have my sermona drained again and they removed my sterile strips. I was dreading seeing it. I had this image in my head which looked nothing like it does. I'm so pleased. There's a neat cut around my nipple and only a slight dent which you only see if you're looking for it (and it's still green/blue from the dye). I really hope when I go for my results next week that I don't have to have more surgery but even if I do I'm going to take this week with being happy!
Posts.Title: Feeling pleased

Posts.Content: I took sage tablets for my hot flushes (menopause) before I went on the HRT - which obviously has now been stopped but I will be getting some more tomorrow as they worked for me last time
Posts.Title: Very bad flushes

Posts.Content: I'd definitely ring the unit as the results come from them. Recently I've had so many things lost in the post. I always ring if I'm waiting for an appointment to come through etc, I would hate to miss anything. Good luck Jo x
Posts.Title: Still waiting for mammogram results

Posts.Content: Hi Jo, I saw genetics 4 years ago after my aunt was diagnosed with ovarian cancer. My mum had breast cancer when she was 51. It was a long appointment and they took down family history etc but I was told then I didnt qualify for testing but they recommended annual mammogram, which my hospital didn't agree with and never offered. When I was diagnosed in August 16 I contacted my genetic consultant. She took my email as a self referral. When I saw her she gave me the blood form there and then. Said Id jumped right up the scale by having the breast cancer at 44. Said I didn't need counselling before. Six weeks to the day she phoned me with a negative result. My aunt who has had ovarian cancer for 4 years has been offered the same test, but she's having to have counselling before they do it. I guess every hospital have their own guidelines. Good luck. Before you go write down your family history, my mind goes blank on those places!  Jo xx
Posts.Title: Genetics testing

Posts.Content: hi Emily, I went straight to breast unit and didn't see my gp at all. Give them a call this morning and have a chat. Hopefully they'll be as nice as mine are and be able to guide you. Good luck xx
Posts.Title: Sudden pain when pressed

Posts.Content: Hi Emj, I can relate completely to your feelings.  I'm 44 and I had a feeling something wasn't right.  I never had a lump nor any visual changes (everything you're told to look out for I didn't have), only 'a feeling'.  I was very lucky that when I phoned the breast unit asking if I needed to go via my GP or if they would send me an appointment I was taken seriously.  That was less than a month ago.  It was confirmed Monday and I'm having surgery next Thursday. I'm feeling pretty dizzy.  This only happens to people we read about in the magazines.  I have 5 girls ranging from 9-25, I'm worrying about them. I'm feeling very positive about my surgery - until my surgery then I'll be really anxious until I get the results! Whatever you feel, it's normal as it's your feeling. Take care and all the best x
Posts.Title: New to the group and Not quite sure what I should be feeling?

Posts.Content: Hello I was always in the unit for around 4 hours from start to finish. I saw Dr first, then waiting to be canulated (having arm in bucket of warm water took a while). There are lots of magazines there. We would take sandwiches as my appointment was over lunch and hospital food shops can be pricey. There was somewhere to make tea and coffee on the unit. Good luck Jo
Posts.Title: How long do Chemo treatments take?

Posts.Content: I'd definitely phone them as they go into the main artery. When I had mine (was checking heart so could be different), I wasn't allowed to use the arm that had been used for 24 hours as you are at risk of bleeding. Phone them and check  Jo x
Posts.Title: Angiogram

Posts.Content: I've been put on them as Tamoxifen didn't agree with me. Only been on two weeks but have noticed aching bones already. My biggest problem at the moment is I have zero energy. Even typing this is a struggle. Could this be the tablets? I already have B12 injections so that's in my favour. Does it ever stop?! Jo xx
Posts.Title: is letrozole really to blame

Posts.Content: I started a blog yesterday, wish I'd done it sooner. I'm lucky I've not really had a bad day yet. I'm just sharing my experience. josjubblygetscancer.com If anyone is interested xx
Posts.Title: Keep a diary

Posts.Content: Morning, I hope you are feeling a bit better now. Don't be hard on yourself, we may have breast cancer but that doesn't stop us being a human being. People with bc have feelings too Reminds me of a time my health visitor came found. I kept apologising for the mess of the children's toys everywhere. She told me she'd be worried if there weren't any. I had my long hair cut to a pixie cut three weeks ago when I was told I'll be having chemo. I start on Friday and today I'm going for my wig fitting. This is the most exciting day for me for months.  Take care of yourself. Jo xx
Posts.Title: I think the poop has hit the fan

Posts.Content: I went in yesterday to have my PICC line fitted. The vein she'd normally use was thrombosed so she tried another. That one was pretty much attached to the artery. She managed to get into it but when threading the wire it kept getting stuck so had to abort. I'm now booked in for next Wednesday for the consultant radiographer to do it in theatre by injecting dye.  I'm now dreading chemo on Friday as they've used the only two veins I have! Anyone else had this? She did say it only happens to 2/3 patients a year so I am special! Regards Jo
Posts.Title: PICC line aborted

Posts.Content: Hello, welcome to the forum.  New here too, I'm 44, had a mammogram 20th July, recall and biopsy 8th August, results 15th and lumpectomy last Thursday. It's all gone very quick but I'm feeling very positive. I was told when they did the biopsy that they were very concerned and worried. The breast care nurse told me that the doctors are not usually wrong and to prepare myself for the cancer diagnosis the following week. I hope you get a positive result next week. Whatever the result, there are people on here who have lived it, and are living it. Each of us are different but joined with this horrible disease. Take care Jo xxx
Posts.Title: I'm 43 saw a dimpling on the breast and went for a routine referr...
